newsitem.title: USA: Conn. Gov. Rowland's approval slips in poll.
newsitem.headline: Conn. Gov. Rowland's approval slips in poll.

text.p: Connecticut Gov. John Rowland's approval rating among voters has slipped to 56 - 34 percent, from 63 - 28 percent in February, according to a Quinnipiac College Poll released Wednesday.

In a hypothetical match-up for the 1998 governor's race, Democratic U.S. Rep. Barbara Kennelly gets 44 percent to Republican Rowland's 40 percent, with 12 percent undecided -- a statistical tie, the poll found.

"This latest poll is mixed news for Gov. Rowland," said Poll Director Douglas Schwartz. "The good news is that most Connecticut voters approve of the job he is doing and he defeats all of his potential opponents -- except one."
"The bad news is that his approval rating is down slightly and that one possible challenger -- Rep. Barbara Kennelly -- ties him in a head-to-head match-up."

The poll found that Rowland held a comfortable lead over other possible Democratic challengers, including former state Comptroller Bill Curry, New Haven Mayor John DeStefano, House Speaker Tom Ritter and Bridgeport Mayor Joseph Ganim.
Curry, who lost to Rowland by only three points in 1994, now trails Rowland by 13 points, or by a margin of 35 percent to 48 percent in a hypothetical, one-on-one match-up.
Quinnipiac College surveyed some 782 Connecticut residents who are registered voters. The poll was conducted July 8-13, with a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percent.
